Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides support for the Nuclear Science Laboratory (NSL) at the University of Notre Dame for an experimental program in low energy nuclear physics. The program is primarily focused on critical issues in nuclear astrophysics, addressing questions about fusion reactions in stars and stellar explosions, how they produce the energy that is released and how they build up all the elements that are observed in our universe. A broad experimental agenda is planned to measure these reactions in the NSL laboratory using a number of different experimental techniques and accelerators. Nuclear reactions that drive stellar explosions will also be studied at larger scale laboratories that can provide rare ion beams that are not available at the NSL facilities. These efforts will primarily take place at Argonne National Laboratory and at the National Super Conducting Cyclotron Laboratory at Michigan State University.

The second mission of the laboratory is the study of the structure of the nucleus. Here the planned experiments focus on measuring the behavior and characteristics of nuclear matter, ranging from mapping special vibrational modes to the incompressibility of matter. These measurements will primarily be done at the Research Center for Nuclear Physics in Osaka, Japan, since no comparable US facility is presently available.

The third goal of this work is to further develop a broad program of nuclear science applications by focusing on high sensitivity methods such as Accelerator Mass Spectrometry and x- and gamma ray spectroscopy. These techniques benefit a broad array of academic fields, including astrophysics, geology, biology, archaeology, and history. Finally, the research provides a rich, hands-on environment for training undergraduate and graduate students in nuclear science, who will then have skills applicable to homeland security and other critical areas.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research at the Nuclear Science Laboratory (NSL) at Notre Dame covers three major areas in low energy nuclear physics, Nuclear Astrophysics, the structure of the nucleus, and nuclear applications. Relevant questions in these three disciplines are attacked and answered using a broad portfolio if instrumentation at the NSL as well as at other nuclear physics laboratories worldwide.

For Nuclear Astrophysics the NSL researchers have followed a multifaceted experimental program coupled with theoretical predictions and simulations of reaction and nucleosynthesis processes. The following outcomes have been achieved: the most important nuclear reactions producing the energy and neutrinos in our sun have been studies with high accuracy to achieve a better handle on neutrino observations for describing the solar interior. Reactions typical for burning in red giant stars such as Betelgeuse have been investigated to predict late stellar evolution towards the death of a star. Critical reactions that define the onset of stellar explosions from novae, X-Ray bursts to supernovae have been investigated to get a better handle on modeling these events. Stellar explosions are spectacular events, including thousands of nuclear processes; systematic analyses were performed to identify the most critical ones for simulating these events. The results serve as guidelines for experiments at the NSL, ANL, NSCL and elsewhere. In particular, the sensitivity study of structure and reaction parameters of nuclei at the r-process path serve as guideline for future experiments at FRIB. Features of nuclear matter have been investigated, in particular its incompressibility, which is important for understanding neutron stars.

The latter study was based on investigating vibration such as the giant resonances in nuclei which is a collective form of vibration of nuclei. In addition to these measurements many other features of nuclear vibrational and rotational modes in the nucleus have been investigated with the ultimate goal of understanding the nucleus as complex multi-particle quantum system in its different configurations as single particle, cluster, and collective particle agglomeration.

Nuclear applications at the NSL cover a wide range, they include for critical experiments for fusion environments such as the National Ignition Facility, to the investigation of alternative reactor types such as the Boron Reactor. They also cover analytical methods from long term storage of radioactive waste to the investigation of archaeological materials and environmental samples using PIXE, PIGE, and XRF techniques. The effort in nuclear applications branches into the study of cosmic and geological materials to probe the evolution of the early solar system.

For all these efforts a broad portfolio of novel instrumentation has been developed; the high intensity Pelletron accelerator represents the back-bone of the nuclear astrophysics program. A unique tool is the St. George recoil separator who can detect a miniscule number of reaction products with a sensitivity of 10-15. This separator serves as blue-print for the much larger SECAR separator at the future FRIB facility at Michigan State University. The local experiments are complemented by studies at the recently installed CASPAR accelerator 1 mile underground at Homestake Mine in South Dakota. The location ensures a cosmic background free environment for the experiments.

The AMS program at the NSL is geared towards the analysis of long-lived radioactivities beyond the traditional radiocarbon analysis. The results of 60Fe studies from the deep ocean floor support the claim earth traveling through a supernova remnant 3 Million years ago, generating a large influx of radioactivity in the earth atmosphere.

The TwinSol system is the first radioactive beam system in the US, through a re-design of the two-solenoid system a much broader range of radioactive beams can be provided with intensities that challenge the promised intensities at large scale national facilities. This improvement stimulated a considerably broader research program for local NSL researchers as well as outside users at TwinSol.
